name: NIMZO-INDIAN DEFENSE
uci_moves: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 e7e6 b1c3 f8b4
idea: The most respected defense against 1.d4! With 3...Bb4, Black pins the Nc3 which defends e4. If White wants to play e4, they will have to accept doubled pawns after ...Bxc3. Nimzowitsch's idea was revolutionary: positional control takes precedence over occupying the center. Black gets a healthy structure and harmonious play. It's the favorite opening of positional world champions!
errors_white: Playing e4 without accepting the consequences: after ...Bxc3+ bxc3, the doubled pawns are a weakness
Ignoring the pin: the Nc3 is paralyzed, you must play Qc2, Bd2 or a3 to solve the problem
Developing passively: White has space, they must use it actively
errors_black: Exchanging ...Bxc3 without reason: the Bishop is a good piece, exchanging it must have a purpose
Playing ...d5 too early: blocks the Bc8, prefer ...d6 or ...b6 first
Neglecting the center: ...c5 or ...d5 must come to contest d4
development: Pins the Nc3 - that's the whole idea of the Nimzo!
Attacks d4 - thematic move in many lines
Comes out to b7 (after ...b6) or stays for ...d5 depending on the plan
...Nc6 or ...Nbd7 depending on the chosen structure

traps.name: Doubled Pawn Trap
traps.desc: If White plays 4.e4?! ...Bxc3+ 5.bxc3 d5! attacks the center and the c3-c4 pawns are doubled. AVOID (White): Play 4.Qc2, 4.e3 or 4.Nf3 before e4.

traps.name: Sämisch Variation
traps.desc: 4.a3 Bxc3+ 5.bxc3 - White accepts doubled pawns for the bishop pair and e4. Double-edged position! AVOID (Black): Play ...c5 and ...d5 to attack the fragile center.

traps.name: Rubinstein Trap
traps.desc: 4.e3 is solid. If Black plays ...c5? too fast, 5.Ne2! and the pin is lifted, White prepares a3. AVOID (Black): Play ...0-0 first, then ...d5 or ...c5 depending on the response.

variants.name: Rubinstein Variation
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 e7e6 b1c3 f8b4 e2e3 e8g8 f1d3 d7d5 g1f3 c7c5 e1g1
variants.white_plan: Classical position. cxd5 exd5 creates an isolated pawn. a3 forces the Bishop exchange. Develop and attack d5.
variants.black_plan: Solid structure with ...d5, ...c5. After ...Nc6, ...dxc4, ...Bxc3 depending on timing. ...b6/...Bb7 possible.

variants.name: Classical Variation (Qc2)
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 e7e6 b1c3 f8b4 d1c2 e8g8 a2a3 b4c3 c2c3 b7b6 c1g5
variants.white_plan: Qc2 defends e4 and avoids doubled pawns. After Bxc3 Qxc3, develop e3, Bd3, Nf3, 0-0 with healthy position.
variants.black_plan: ...b6 and ...Bb7 for the fianchetto. The Bb7 targets e4 and g2. ...c5 or ...d5 for central counterplay.

variants.name: Sämisch Variation
variants.uci: d2d4 g8f6 c2c4 e7e6 b1c3 f8b4 a2a3 b4c3 b2c3 c7c5 e2e3 d7d5 c4d5 e6d5
variants.white_plan: The doubled pawns give e4! Play Bd3, Ne2, 0-0, f3 then e4. The bishop pair and center compensate.
variants.black_plan: Attack the c3-c4 pawns! ...Nc6, ...0-0, ...cxd4 then ...Na5 or ...Qa5 to target the weaknesses.
